Award.AwardTitle: Development and Porting of iCons III: Student-Designed Labs in Renewable Energy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: There are daunting technological challenges in bringing the potential of renewable energy such as solar energy and biofuels to fruition, requiring collaboration among leaders in science, engineering, and social science. Despite this need for multidisciplinary integration, university science education remains firmly rooted in separate silos. The University of Massachusetts Amherst (UMass) is tackling this issue through the Integrated Concentration in Science (iCons) program, a new national model of integrative education that sets multidisciplinary student teams to work on current societal problems such as renewable energy. Holyoke Community College (HCC) has likewise developed its own integrative 2-year clean energy program. Jointly they develop a renewable energy laboratory course. The course trains students to design and carry out unique experiments on subjects such as algae biofuels, plastic solar cells, and new energy-efficient building materials. This new UMass/HCC partnership produces students with leadership and laboratory experience in clean energy problems, able to cross disciplinary boundaries in search of useful solutions. The resulting laboratory modules will be disseminated nationally and globally for broadest impact. The partnership produces new pathways for HCC students to transfer to 4-year programs. And most important, the UMass/iCons and HCC programs produce the next generation of leaders in science with the attitudes, knowledge, and skills needed to solve the inherently multidisciplinary technology problems facing our nation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this partnership project, involving the University of Massachusetts Amherst (UMass) and Holyoke Community College (HCC), is to leverage each institution's individual strengths to develop new laboratory courses at each institution that focus on renewable energy. The emphasis is interdisciplinary, team-based, project-based learning. We are building and assessing laboratory curricula that produce the kind of multidisciplinary, collaborative problem-solvers needed to move toward a society that uses renewable energy sustainably. Towards this end, the project worked to address the following questions:

• How should multidisciplinary groups of students be trained to produce effective collaborations?

• What is the optimal balance between instructor-direction and student-design of renewable energy labs?

• How do we create a portable renewable energy lab that can be used at a wide variety of institutions?

The activities involve curriculum development, delivery of the courses, learning assessments, and analysis. At UMass the central focus was a laboratory course for junior-level undergraduates (NatSci 389H: Team-Oriented Lab Discovery in Renewable Energy). The primary objective of this course is for students to develop a high level of “ownership” (self-efficacy) and capability to select, design, carry out and analyze open-ended real-world research projects. This curriculum was also adapted to the needs of faculty at Mount Holyoke Community College and used in one course on energy and another on sustainability.

Ultimately the project resulted in the development of curriculum and infrastructure that works well for a student-lead team learning environment focused on energy science. In terms of pedagogical assessment, over the course of a semester the students were found to have the largest growth in the areas of scientific impact, interdisciplinary teamwork, social impact and interpretation of project objectives. Other institutions can obtain detailed curriculum and collaborative assistance from the website https://icons.cns.umass.edu/ and staff of the UMass iCons program.
